shortExplanation: a distinct part of something
longExplanation: Any of the more or less distinct parts into which something is or may be divided or from which it is made up.

examples.sentence: The library has a large section on history.
The last section of the report summarizes the findings.

synonyms.coreMeaning: An amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something

antonyms.coreMeaning: A thing that is complete in itself

shortExplanation: a geographic or economic area
longExplanation: An area or portion that is distinct from others.

examples.sentence: The financial sector is a major part of the economy.
The company is a leader in the technology sector.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A region or part of a town, a country, or the world

shortExplanation: noticeable, meaningful or important
longExplanation: Sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy.

examples.sentence: There has been a significant increase in the number of students.
The discovery of DNA was a significant moment in the history of science.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Of great significance or value; likely to have a profound effect on success, survival, or well-being

antonyms.coreMeaning: Too small or unimportant to be worth consideration

shortExplanation: almost but not exactly the same
longExplanation: Resembling without being identical.

examples.sentence: The two brothers have similar interests.
The two cars are similar in design.

synonyms.coreMeaning: (of two or more people or things) similar to each other

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not the same as another or each other; unlike in nature, form, or quality

shortExplanation: the cause of something or place it comes from
longExplanation: A place, person, or thing from which something comes or can be obtained.

examples.sentence: The river is a major source of water for the city.
The company is looking for new sources of revenue.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived

shortExplanation: relating to one thing and not others
longExplanation: Clearly defined or identified.

examples.sentence: The doctor gave me specific instructions.
The project has a specific goal.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Used to single out an individual member of a specified group or class

antonyms.coreMeaning: Affecting or concerning all or most people, places, or things; widespread

shortExplanation: the way parts of a system or object are arranged
longExplanation: The arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex.

examples.sentence: The structure of the building is very complex.
The company has a very hierarchical structure.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action, process, or result of arranging or being arranged

shortExplanation: protection of a person, property or organization
longExplanation: The state of being free from danger or threat.

examples.sentence: The company takes security very seriously.
National security is a top priority for the government.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The condition of being protected from or unlikely to cause danger, risk, or injury

antonyms.coreMeaning: The possibility of suffering harm or injury

shortExplanation: simple past and past participle of seek
longExplanation: Attempt to find (something).

examples.sentence: He sought refuge in a nearby church.
The company sought to expand its business.

synonyms.coreMeaning: To search for

shortExplanation: to choose, especially after careful consideration
longExplanation: Carefully choose as being the best or most suitable.

examples.sentence: She was selected to represent the company.
You can select your preferred a few options.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Pick out or select (someone or something) as being the best or most appropriate of two or more alternatives

shortExplanation: a place where something was, is, or will be
longExplanation: An area of ground on which a town, building, or monument is constructed.

examples.sentence: The company is building a new factory on this site.
This is the site of a famous battle.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A particular place or position

shortExplanation: detailed plans or methods for achieving success
longExplanation: A plan of action designed to achieve a long-term or overall aim.

examples.sentence: The company has a new marketing strategy.
The government has a strategy to combat climate change.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A detailed proposal for doing or achieving something

shortExplanation: a series of questions used to gather personal data
longExplanation: A general view, examination, or description of someone or something.

examples.sentence: The company conducted a survey of its customers.
The results of the survey will be published next month.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The process of voting in an election

shortExplanation: an organized plan, or an outline of a system or thing
longExplanation: A large-scale systematic plan or arrangement for attaining a particular object or putting a particular idea into effect.

examples.sentence: The government has a new scheme to help the unemployed.
The company has a very complex organizational scheme.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A detailed proposal for doing or achieving something

shortExplanation: a series, or the order in which things are arranged
longExplanation: A particular order in which related events, movements, or things follow each other.

examples.sentence: The book describes the sequence of events that led to the war.
The dance is a sequence of simple steps.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The arrangement or disposition of people or things in relation to each other according to a particular sequence, pattern, or method

shortExplanation: the state of being either female or male
longExplanation: Either of the two main categories (male and female) into which humans and most other living things are divided on the basis of their reproductive functions.

examples.sentence: The company does not discriminate on the basis of sex.
The doctor asked about the patient's sex.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The state of being male or female (typically used with reference to social and cultural differences rather than biological ones)

shortExplanation: a change in position, direction or conditions
longExplanation: Move or cause to move from one place to another, especially over a small distance.

examples.sentence: He shifted his weight from one foot to the other.
The company has shifted its focus to a new market.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Go in a specified direction or manner; change position

shortExplanation: stated clearly or described accurately
longExplanation: Identify clearly and definitely.

examples.sentence: The contract specified the terms of the agreement.
The report specified the need for further research.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Express something definitely or clearly in speech or writing

shortExplanation: as much as is needed for a particular purpose
longExplanation: Enough; adequate.

examples.sentence: We have sufficient food for everyone.
The company has sufficient resources to complete the project.

synonyms.coreMeaning: As much or as many as required

shortExplanation: a sequence of similar or related things
longExplanation: A number of things, events, or people of a similar kind or related nature coming one after another.

examples.sentence: The television series was very popular.
The company has launched a new series of products.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A particular order in which related events, movements, or things follow each other

shortExplanation: a branch of applied mathematics that analyzes data
longExplanation: The practice or science of collecting and analyzing numerical data in large quantities, especially for the purpose of inferring proportions in a whole from those in a representative sample.

examples.sentence: Statistics show that the crime rate has decreased.
She is studying statistics at university.

shortExplanation: the relative position of someone or something
longExplanation: The relative social, professional, or other standing of someone or something.

examples.sentence: He has a high social status.
The company's financial status is very strong.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A place where someone or something is located or has been put

shortExplanation: to give emphasis or special attention to something
longExplanation: A state of mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or very demanding circumstances.

examples.sentence: She is under a lot of stress at work.
The teacher stressed the importance of studying for the exam.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The use of persuasion, influence, or intimidation to make someone do something

shortExplanation: happening after something else
longExplanation: Coming after something in time; following.

examples.sentence: The book was a huge success, and a subsequent movie was made.
Subsequent events proved him right.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Coming after or as a result of

antonyms.coreMeaning: Existing or occurring before in time or order

shortExplanation: the total number or amount of things added together
longExplanation: A particular amount of money.

examples.sentence: The sum of 2 and 3 is 5.
He paid a large sum of money for the car.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A number or amount of things added or collected together

shortExplanation: a short description of the main points of something
longExplanation: A brief statement or account of the main points of something.

examples.sentence: The report provides a summary of the findings.
She gave a brief summary of the book.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A summary of the contents of a book, article, or formal speech

shortExplanation: resistance to change, or constancy of character
longExplanation: The state of being stable.

examples.sentence: Political stability is important for economic growth.
The company is in a period of financial stability.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The quality of being steady

antonyms.coreMeaning: The state of being unstable; lack of stability

shortExplanation: types, expressions, or ways of doing something
longExplanation: A particular kind, sort, or type, as regards form, appearance, or character.

examples.sentence: There are many different styles of music.
She has a very unique sense of style.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A category of people or things having common characteristics

shortExplanation: the replacement of one thing by another
longExplanation: The action of replacing someone or something with another person or thing.

examples.sentence: The coach made a substitution in the second half.
The company is using a substitution for the original ingredient.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action or process of replacing someone or something

shortExplanation: able to be continued or maintained
longExplanation: Able to be maintained at a certain rate or level.

examples.sentence: The company is committed to sustainable development.
We need to find a sustainable solution to the problem.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Able to be maintained

shortExplanation: representing something else, or ineffective
longExplanation: Serving as a symbol.

examples.sentence: The dove is a symbolic of peace.
The gesture was purely symbolic.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Typical of a class, group, or body of opinion

shortExplanation: range covered, or opportunity
longExplanation: The extent of the area or subject matter that something deals with or to which it is relevant.

examples.sentence: The scope of the project is very large.
The book is beyond the scope of this course.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The area of variation between upper and lower limits on a particular scale

shortExplanation: of lesser importance
longExplanation: Less important than but related or supplementary to.

examples.sentence: The company has several subsidiaries.
This is a subsidiary issue.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Coming after, less important than, or resulting from someone or something else that is primary

shortExplanation: model of the essential features of a process or thing
longExplanation: The imitation of the operation of a real-world process or system over time.

examples.sentence: The company uses computer simulations to test its new products.
The pilot is training in a flight simulator.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A thing intended to simulate or copy something else

shortExplanation: only and exclusively
longExplanation: Not involving anyone or anything else; only.

examples.sentence: The company is solely responsible for the accident.
He is solely focused on his career.

synonyms.coreMeaning: And no one or nothing more besides; solely or exclusively

shortExplanation: slightly or rather
longExplanation: To a moderate extent or degree.

examples.sentence: I was somewhat surprised by the news.
The movie was somewhat disappointing.

synonyms.coreMeaning: To a small degree; not considerably

shortExplanation: presented for consideration, or gave in to
longExplanation: Accept or yield to a superior force or to the authority or will of another person.

examples.sentence: He submitted his resignation.
She submitted her application for the job.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Give or award formally or ceremonially

shortExplanation: following in sequence and without a break
longExplanation: Following one another or following others.

examples.sentence: The company has had five successive years of growth.
He won the championship for the third successive year.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Following continuously

shortExplanation: to continue to live or exist
longExplanation: Continue to live or exist, especially in spite of danger or hardship.

examples.sentence: He was lucky to survive the accident.
The company is struggling to survive.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Suffer (something painful or difficult) patiently

antonyms.coreMeaning: Die, especially in a violent or sudden way

shortExplanation: a plan of activities organized by time
longExplanation: A plan for carrying out a process or procedure, giving lists of intended events and times.

examples.sentence: The train is on schedule.
I have a very busy schedule today.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A chart or plan of events, classes, etc., arranged according to the time at which they are scheduled to take place

shortExplanation: imagined event, or model of expected outcomes
longExplanation: A postulated sequence or development of events.

examples.sentence: The worst-case scenario is that we lose all our money.
The movie has a very interesting scenario.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A set of circumstances in which one finds oneself; a state of affairs

shortExplanation: area of interest, knowledge or control
longExplanation: An area of activity, interest, or expertise; a section of society or an aspect of life distinguished and unified by a particular characteristic.

examples.sentence: He is a leading figure in the political sphere.
The company is expanding its sphere of influence.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A region or part of a town, a country, or the world

shortExplanation: of less importance or lower status
longExplanation: Lower in rank or position.

examples.sentence: He has several subordinate employees.
This is a subordinate issue.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Lower in rank, status, or quality

antonyms.coreMeaning: Higher in rank, status, or quality

shortExplanation: extra, or supplying what is lacking
longExplanation: Completing or enhancing something.

examples.sentence: The company provides supplementary health insurance.
The book includes a supplementary chapter on the latest research.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Added, extra, or supplementary to what is already present or available

shortExplanation: stopped something temporarily or permanently
longExplanation: Temporarily prevent from continuing or being in force or effect.

examples.sentence: The student was suspended from school.
The project has been suspended due to lack of funding.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Cause or arrange for (something) to take place at a time later than that first scheduled

shortExplanation: commonly or falsely called
longExplanation: Used to show that something or someone is commonly designated by a particular name or term but that the name or term is questionable or used reluctantly.

examples.sentence: The so-called expert was not able to answer the question.
The so-called cure was actually harmful.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Said, without proof, to have taken place or to have a specified illegal or undesirable quality

shortExplanation: easy to understand, or honest and frank
longExplanation: Uncomplicated and easy to do or understand.

examples.sentence: The instructions were straightforward.
He is a very straightforward person.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Easily understood or done; presenting no difficulty

antonyms.coreMeaning: Consisting of many interconnecting parts or elements
